 I suspect what you might be suggesting here is that Stalin was not really committed to the ideology of Marxist-Leninism, but that he was an unscrupulous freelance tyrant who used Communist doctrines as a camouflage under which he manipulated his way to power ? Then having got to the summit in Soviet Russia, perhaps you think he affected a belief in Marxist principles in order to maintain himself as a despot ?
 
 There is something to be said for this view. Stalin, unlike Lenin, was not a political theorist and he contributed little if anything to "Marxist thought". But he certainly acted as if he wanted to reconcile every aspect of policy with Marxist-Leninist principles, even if he was only paying lip service to the ideas that were supposed to be at the core of his political philosophy. 
 
 A few examples of his Leninist inheritance: (apart from the 5 year plans designed to secure production by force, and the drives towards collectivism).
 
 he effected complete control of all media for propaganda purposes.
 he systematically eliminated opposition without respect for law or morality.
 he demanded unswerving dogmatism in all matters, regardless of competence.
 he justified such measures as being necessary in achieving a "workers state" - on the road to that socialist utopia in which the dictatorship of the proletariat would be realized. 
 
 It could be argued that his interpretation of Marxist-Leninism resulted in a new species of revolutionary politics called Stalinism - and that this "novelty" is an unavoidable consequence of the attempt to elucidate Marxist doctrine as a program of action rather than a theory of history.
